issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Create a document which is focused on explaining which versions of which noteworthy components will work (or are known not to work, etc) with which versions of other products. Likewise, these references in existing documentation can be minimized and linked to the Support Matrix.

The format should be tabular, with footnotes as appropriate.

Examples of items which should be considered for inclusion:

- Eucalyptus cloud
- euca2ools
- RHEL
- CentOS
- NetApp

The Support Matrix should ideally encompass all Eucalyptus product versions which have not reached EOL. It may be a good idea to include EOL'd versions indefinitely, being clear to indicate that they are indeed EOL, even if it's just a footnote. 

Maintaining older info as well as 'current' info should help provide clarity, both for organizations wanting to have the latest version of everything, as well as organizations wanting to have a clear understanding for older versions and wanting to keep within the boundaries of "supported and known to work".

comments.body:
An attempt to clarify SANs within the Matrix:

|| Eucalyptus version || SAN vendor/product || SAN model ||
| 3.2 | Dell EquaLogic | PS4000 series & PS6000 series \[[#0]\] \[[#3]\] |
| 3.2 | NetApp Filer | FAS2000 series & FAS6000 series \[[#1]\] \[[#4]\] \[[#6]\] |
| 3.2 | EMC | VNC Series \[[#2]\] \[[#5]\] |
| 3.4 | Dell EquaLogic | PS4000 series & PS6000 series \[[#0]\] \[[#3]\] |
| 3.4 | NetApp Filer | FAS2000 series & FAS6000 series \[[#1]\] \[[#4]\] \[[#6]\] |
| 3.4 | EMC | VNC Series \[[#2]\] \[[#5]\] |

{anchor:0}\[0\] For more information about Dell EqualLogic SANs, go to http://www.dell.com
{anchor:1}\[1\] For more information about NetApp SANs, go to http://www.netapp.com
{anchor:2}\[2\] For more information about EMC VNX, go to [VNX Family|http://www.emc.com/storage/vnx/vnx-family.htm]
{anchor:3}\[3\] Eucalyptus requires SSH access to enable automatic provisioning
{anchor:4}\[4\] Eucalyptus manages NetApp SANs via ONTAPI (version 7.3.3 and above)
{anchor:5}\[5\] Eucalyptus requires EMC NaviSecCLI software to be installed on the Storage Controller host
{anchor:6}\[6\] NetApp E-series run on SANtricity, which is *not* supported in this version of Eucalyptus

With regards to RHEL / CentOS install platforms, something like this:

|| Eucalyptus || euca2ools || RHEL || CentOS ||
| 3.4.2 | 3.0.2 | 5.9, 5.10, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5 | 5.9, 5.10, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5 |
| 3.4.1 | 3.0.2 | 5.9, 5.10, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5 | 5.9, 5.10, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5 |
| 3.4.0 | 3.0.1 | 5.9, 5.10, 6.3, 6.4 | 5.9, 5.10, 6.3, 6.4 | 

The above is somewhat speculative on my part, in particular regarding the range of major.minor versions of RHEL/CentOS we would support. Would it be better to say something like "6.x through to 6.5" as a baseline, and build upon that going forward?

[~jcarroll], this is looking great. I took ownership of this and flagged it for 4.0.0. Let me know when you think it's done-ish, and I'll put it into an XML table and include it in the docs. Initially, I think I'll include it as an appendix in the Install Guide--maybe link to it in the main doc landing page. Thoughts?

[~smarvin], it does seem to be most appropriate as an appendix entry due to the present small size. The only gotcha there is for those folks who download the PDF files instead.

Also with regards to the OS versions, how flexible should we be on that? Should we allow for any version of RHEL/CentOS, or should we limit it somewhat, eg, nothing older than 5.0? While some organizations like to be on the bleeding edge of applications and OSes, some organizations may freeze their version of Eucalyptus while allowing the OS to be updated/upgraded over time.

Should we also add a footnote to clearly state which combinations have been tested in QA?

I'm also wondering whether we should add a section with regards to upgrade path. Reference: https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html#install-guide/upgrade.html

Specifically:

"You can upgrade to Eucalyptus 3.4.2 from either 3.3.2 or 3.4.1. You can use the same instructions for either version."

I had a recent ticket where they wanted to upgrade from 3.2.2 to 3.4.2 I directed them to first upgrade to 3.4.1, then upgrade CentOS to 6.5, then continue with upgrading from 3.4.1 to 3.4.2.

Sorry, the quote in that last update was a caffeine-deficit moment.

The quote should read:

"You can upgrade to Eucalyptus 3.4.2 from either 3.3.2 or 3.4.1. You can use the same instructions for either version.

To upgrade from any other version of Eucalyptus, you must first upgrade to either 3.3.2 or 3.4.1. Follow the directions in that version's Installation Guide in the documentation archives, and then upgrade to 3.4.2 using the directions in this section."

Hey [~jcarroll], where does this stand in your view? Is the information ready? I'm not going to have any cycles to do much, if anything, for 4.0.0. So, if this information is necessary for 4.0.0, we'll need to have someone else create all of the content.

Hi [~scot.marvin@eucalyptus.com], it's about as ready as I'm able to make it at this point. I'm sure that others who have had a lengthier exposure to the product may be able to provide more data based on personal experience.

We've got the thin edge of the wedge started. We'll (collectively) continue to tap on the blunt end as our experiences help to guide us in this regard.

[~jcarroll], I'm rethinking about where this matrix doc should reside. I have two reasons for this.

First, we try to not specify versions of things when we can get away with it in the documentation--unless we can use a variable for it (we do this, for example, for both the current and previous versions of a product).

Second, each documentation release is version specific. So, it's a little odd to refer to a matrix with past versions in the current doc.

I think we need this matrix, but outside the documentation set. I don't mind pulling in a subset of the information into each current documentation release. I think that's a good thing.

We don't have much time to design and write anything for 4.0.0--we're barely making our minimum feature set requirements. So, for 4.0.0, I'll concentrate on the matrix. However, we still need to figure out what our requirements are for 4.0.0.

[~kristina@eucalyptus.com], do you have any recommendations about where this matrix should reside? I can link to it from the main documentation page. Should I just add it there? It wouldn't appear anywhere in the TOC.

[~smarvin], I'm all for having it as its own, separate document. I'll forward you an example via email to help provide some context.

To your points:

1. I'm all for not specifying versions, for those things which are unlikely to be affected by versions. One exception which springs to mind is the recent version sensitivity of QEMU. The exposure left by not putting boundaries on what is supported is that we are implicitly obligated to support everything. By expressly saying "this has been QA'd" or "this has been trivially tested" or "we've heard rumors that this works" or similar will help to guide our customers down the right path, or at least help to avoid the wrong path.

2. The matrix will probably need to live outside of the standard doc tree versioning. Or at least be loosely coupled, rather than strict. Otherwise we're back to the original challenge of helping customers who are running older versions of <thing> (most likely older versions of Eucalyptus itself) wanting to upgrade <other thing> (most likely the underlying OS) being able to find the older version of the docs on our website. For customers who are on what they feel is a stable version of Eucalyptus, but are interested in being on the latest version of RHEL/CentOS, I would expect them to eventually run into an issue after upgrading RHEL/CentOS to some version. Perhaps not today, but can we make that guarantee with RHEL 7.x? 8.x? If we learn (through a support ticket or QA testing or other vector) that a previously untested combination has been successfully tested, then the matrix can be updated accordingly. Another row or column added, or another version added to a table cell, etc.

Given the time crunch for 4.0.0, do what you need to do. This can wait a bit to be fleshed out.

I really like this link:

https://www.eucalyptus.com/eucalyptus-cloud/iaas/compatibility

As of this writing, it's focused on Eucalyptus 3.4.2.

What isn't clear here is where someone who has 3.3.2 installed will go to get similar info. Or once 4.0 is released, where this info for 3.4.2 users will end up.

Don't really need answers today, this is merely food for thought.

I think this is where the matrix should be.


On Tue, Apr 22, 2014 at 9:28 AM, Jim Carroll (JIRA) <

[~jcarroll], [~scot.marvin@eucalyptus.com] The archive compatibility matrices are linked from the bottom of that page (not very visible, indeed). https://www.eucalyptus.com/eucalyptus-cloud/iaas/compatibility/archive

Have moved the link to the top of the page to make it more visible.
[~jcarroll] If you have suggestions for improving the compatibility matrix, [~shashimc] is the owner of that content.

[~kristina@eucalyptus.com] thanks for tweaking the link to the older versions. Didn't know it was right there in front of me.

I'm really jazzed by how this matrix looks! Very slick. The only thing which I keep coming back to is the QEMU issue. Is this merely an outlier?

Other than that, the only other thing which springs to mind is having a link from http://eucalyptus.com/docs back to the above compatibility matrix.

Okay, since we have a place on the website, I've created a link to the
page. The link is on the main documentation landing page, at the bottom
with the other "Looking for" links.

My understanding is that support will update this page and that
documentation's role in this done. If this is not the case, let me know.

If this is the case, let's close out this ticket.


On Tue, Apr 22, 2014 at 2:51 PM, Jim Carroll (JIRA) <

Whoops, I think I was unintentionally ambiguous.

When I go here:

https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/3.4/index.html

I do see a link to here:

https://www.eucalyptus.com/eucalyptus-cloud/documentation/archive

but I don't see a link to here:

https://www.eucalyptus.com/eucalyptus-cloud/iaas/compatibility

Also, which page were you referring to when you indicated an understanding that support would update it?

Sorry Jim, I meant that the doc was changed for 4.0.0. It won't be
reflected on the web site until we release.


On Thu, Apr 24, 2014 at 12:09 PM, Jim Carroll (JIRA) <

That makes sense, of course.

Yeah, I'd say we can close this DOC. Thanks for your patience!
